utterances: I was concerned because he should have had at least one, which was mine.
And they were saying he had none.
And you know, what happened when you went to vote in the primary?
The first thing that happened is when I went in, normally, you know, you are registered in the book that they have and they seemed to could not have found my name, first off.
So in light of the fact that my name not being in the book, they told me I had to use the absentee ballot in order to have my vote registered.
So I used the absentee ballot, thinking that would be counted, and then, like I said, come to find out they were saying he didn't have any votes.
Did you feel initially that casting an absentee ballot was going to - did you fear that it was going to put your vote at risk just to cast an absentee ballot as opposed to a regular ballot?
I did, because when I voted the last time, I didn't feel that my vote was counted either.
Now, do you know if the vote actually did count in these revised versions?
Do you have any sense, Sandra, of whether or not your vote counted in the end?
No.
Sam, what about that?
Do you think that her vote was counted in the end?
Well, I think, frankly, that it probably was counted.
It's very important to remember - the Board of Elections keeps reminding us of this - that the count on election night is a very, very unofficial, informal count.
It's done for the inconvenience of the press and obviously by extension to the public.
But then under the law, the Board of Elections conducts its official canvas, which may take weeks.

It involves a count from the back of the machines, which certainly would have corrected those clerical errors in the first count, and then to that they add the absentee ballots and to that they add the affidavit ballots, people probably like Sandra who showed up at the polls and they couldn't find a registration.
But she swore on a ballot that she was in fact entitled to vote and therefore, they gave her an affidavit and it presumably counted.
So again, it doesn't instill much faith in the process, for sure, and it shows how haphazard it can sometimes be.
But it is a reminder that those votes that come out on election night or primary night are unofficial ones.
Communities need to be aware of those risks when doing community planning, not to build in very high-hazard areas.
And we need to build smarter.
Just like you.
Nice job.
I found out that several other people had the same problem, where their names weren't listed in the book and we'd been voting there for years.
And now all of a sudden, they couldn't find our registration and we had - we were forced basically to use the absentee ballot.
And did people talk about, for example, talking to a city coucil person or did you just say, well, you know, this is too bad and I don't know what to do about it?
What action did you specifically take afterwards, if any?
We didn't.
We just kind of felt a little upset about it, and we waited to hear what the outcome would be.
And then once we heard that, you know, he had no votes for Harlem, then we then at that point felt that, you know, our initial response was that it wouldn't be counted is what happened.

Sam, we asked the New York City Board of Elections to respond to the story, and a representative said that the issues were for the most part people showing up to the wrong polling place or voters not being properly registered for the primary, some people changing their names and not reporting a name change.

And so looking, you know, from a, you know, a thousand-mile-up perspective, do there need to be some changes, you think, that make things easier for voters to understand how they need to register, whether it's on a party level, whether it's, you know, all of these other issues of name and address?
Is that part of the problem?
Well, I think there are two problems.
One is the public need to be better educated and informed, that's for sure.
And the rules as we've seen with people closely following the contests in many different states this year and the end of last year show there are different rules in different states.
So people may not be familiar with the rules when you have to register, how late you can change parties, before the primary, things like that.
The other problem, as Mayor Bloomberg in New York correctly points out, is that the Board of Elections is about the last vestige of formal patronage left in New York.
It is very much controlled by the Democratic and Republican political organizations, has resisted for any number of reasons anything resembling efficiency or competence.
And you've got a number of officials there trying to do their best against a system that just doesn't generate efficiency and productivity and great competence, frankly.
And I think that's one of the big problems that New York voters have always had to face.
Sandra, if you were going to give some advice to someone who's going to vote either in one of the upcoming primaries or just in the general election in November, what would you say?
Actually, I'm not really sure.
I was going to ask for some advice because I was concerned, like I said, with the fact with my name not being in the book.
Is there something that I need to check, to find out, retrace, you know, in order to find out what went wrong?
Sam, we have very little time, but what advice would you give?
I think that's a very good idea.

I think you should call the Board of Elections and make sure that you are enrolled and if they can't do that over the phone, then ask them to send you an enrollment form so you can re-enroll to make sure that for November, you won't have any trouble voting at all.
All right.
Well, both of you, it's been great talking.
Thanks so much.
Thank you.
Thank you.

Baseball history is stuffed with nicknames - The Babe, The Splendid Splinter, The Big Hurt, Derek Daffy, Hammerin' Hank, Leo the Lip, El Duque, and lots and lots of Dutches, Reds, and Peewees.
But Gary Cieradkowski, a noted artist, illustrator and baseball historian, has written and illustrated a book about baseball players and stories that are often overlooked and unheralded.
The League of Outsider Baseball"" - an illustrated history of baseball's forgotten heroes.

And Gary Cieradkowski - who's done previous books on baseball cards and has designed playing cards and coffee cans and parts of Oriole Park at Camden Yards - joins us now from the studios of WVXU in Cincinnati.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Thanks for having me on.
You have a section here that really makes you reflect on life - the could-have-beens, if you please - players who were on their way to becoming heroes when something happens.
Right, I got the love of that from my grandfather.
He was a Brooklyn Dodger fan going all the way back to the 1930s.
And when I was a kid, I was a Mets fan, and this is in the late '70s or early '80s.
There really wasn't a lot of good things to talk about when you're a Mets fan.
So I would sit on the porch with my grandfather, and he would start talking to me about the old Brooklyn Dodgers.
And, you know, he'd talk about people like Dazzy Vance and Duke Snider and Jackie Robinson, but then he'd start talking about a guy named Pete Reiser.
Pete played in the early 1940s.
And he would get this glazed look in his eye - this sad, faraway look - when he would tell about Pete Reiser.
And he would say that he was probably the best ballplayer that ever played.
And I was fairly well-read as a kid on baseball history, but I had never heard of Pete Reiser.
So it made me get into baseball history and try to find those players that had an interesting story, which led me to find out what had happened to Pete Reiser and his career.
There are people who will tell you that Pete Reiser was the best of all time, except for the fact he kept running into walls.
He is credited with having five outfield collisions, and 11 times he was carried away off the field on a stretcher.
Nine of those times he was unconscious.
And today, he's the reason why Major League Baseball has padded outfield walls.
Another name that has been lost to history - Steve Dalkowski.
Yeah.
They say that he's the fastest pitcher there ever was.
It's just he really couldn't find home plate.
I mean, some of the stories you learn about this guy, it reads like fiction.
When he was - I think this is around 1960.
He's pitching in the minor leagues, and he pitched so fast he ripped the man's ear off.
Oh.
Yeah.
And Steve Dalkowski didn't make it to the Hall of Fame because...
Adrian Todd, the associate director, says there's also basketball and swimming for teenagers in the summer teen program.
He just couldn't find home plate.
And eventually, one of his minor league managers found some way to just simplify pitching for Dalkowski - just throw strikes, just throw strikes.
So it all came together for him in the spring of 1963 after about four or five years of trying to get to the major leagues.
And he finally makes the Orioles's roster.
They fit him for a set of uniforms.
Topps baseball cards comes around, takes his picture, makes it on a rookie card in the 1963 set, but by the time the cards hit the shelf, he was nowhere to be seen.
In the final game before the season started, he's playing the Yankees and something popped in his arm, and that was it.
Boy.
And you have a personal friend - Leon Day - similar story about the capriciousness of fate, I guess.
Yeah.
He played in the Negro leagues.
But they had just as stiff competition as the major leagues back then.
And for a time before World War II, he was just as good as Satchel Paige, people say, or sometimes say even better.
And I met him when I was going to art school in Baltimore.

And I didn't understand how great a player he was 'cause he was so soft spoken and all he would do - I'd sit for hours with him in his house and he would just talk about all these great players that he had played against.

And I started going to newspaper archives and, you know, you read the contemporary accounts and then you talk to some of the old players that had played with him or against him, and they're saying that this guy was just phenomenal.
He actually wound up getting elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.
And unfortunately, he was in the hospital at the time.
And he passed away a few days after he was notified that he was a Hall of Famer, which is bittersweet, but it's great that he was able to go knowing that.

Yes.
